Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 06:32AM BlessedOne2 wrote: I went in for a routing mammo. On the same day, it turned to a diagnostic mammo, then an ultrasound and then to a core needle biopsy all on the same morning.  Each test confirmed the finding of the other.  So three times in one morning I was told that my results were positive.   I've read that some women had to wait a couple of days.  I think it just depends on where you go.  I went to the Breast Imaging Center of the hospital nearest my home b/c that is where I had been going for my annual routine mammos.
Posts.Title: Surgical biopsy scheduled and scared Firedancer BlessedOne2

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 05:29AM BlessedOne2 wrote: J and Firedancer,  I am a wee bit older at 53 but my experience is very similar to yours.  I'm glad to meet both of you, even though we are here on this board. I have very dense breasts also but because of the location of my lump (rb, upper inner quadrant at 1:00 position), with some struggle it showed up on the mammo.  Firedancer, it is not uncommon for nothing to show up on the mammos.  This was a big surprise to me.  Why do we have to get them every year, hmmmmm?  Anyway, I just had lumpectomy on June 10 - same procedure as Firedancer.  No pain, very little nausea.  The waiting is often the most difficult part through this journey.   But know that every woman's situation is unique to her.    I was diagnosed on April 6 with surgery 65 days later.  Try to focus on your daily routine as best you can.  Forgive me if this sounds harsh, but worrying won't make anything happen any faster or differently.  The date seems soooo far away, but it will come quicker than you realize.  If you are a believer, pray and give your worry to the Lord.  He will give you peace.
Posts.Title: Surgical biopsy scheduled and scared Firedancer BlessedOne2

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 08:43AM BlessedOne2 wrote: Makraz, is the oncotype DX test done automatically? I've already had lumpectomy.
Posts.Title: Surgical biopsy scheduled and scared Firedancer BlessedOne2

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2010 11:12AM BlessedOne2 wrote: Faith22, I had IDC and my tumor was actually just above what we normally refer to as our breast.  This is the most unsettling time - getting news and waiting for tests, to get more information, etc. etc.  A surgeon whom I respect told me "It's good that you found it early, but you really don't know how long it has been there."  This really helped me to keep things in perspective.  A little knowledge can reek havoc on our mind and emotions.  Try to stay in the present and not get so far ahead of things and remember to breath.  The shell shock is normal to.   Hugs and blessings to you.  I shall say a prayer for you tonight.  Wanda
Posts.Title: Just diagnosised faith22 faith22

Posts.Content: BlessedOne2 wrote: Hi All, On March 26, I learned that I have uterine fibroids and a simple cyst on left ovary.  On April 6, one test led to another and another and then biopsy and confirmation of IDC -- all on same day.   Since that time, I put the 4th option given to me for consideration of the fibroids and uterine cyst - do nothing for now. Fast forward, I will see an Internal Med DR on Friday, the sur/onco that I was reassigned to on Mon.  A lumpectomy of right breast is scheduled for June 10. Lesion is high in the upper inner quandrant.   Should I mention the fibroids and cyst to either of them?. A cluster of microcysts also found in my left breast.   Mom passed from BC over 20 yrs ago.  Sister passed last year from gallbladder cancer-mets. A cancerous ovarian cyst was also found.  It was a big surprise to gyno/onco.  Is anyone familiar with microcysts?  Has anyone had a lesion up high in the inner quandrant?  Your experience? What are chances it is very close to chest wall?  If very close, what might I expect in surgery?   I'll stop with these six questions.  I have been helped sooooo much since just recently signing on to the board.  Again thank you for being here.     Dx 4/6/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 6/10/2009 Lumpectomy: Right Chemotherapy 7/15/2009 AC + T (Taxol) Targeted Therapy 11/11/2009 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Radiation Therapy 1/23/2010 Breast Hormonal Therapy 3/5/2010 Arimidex (anastrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Getting Close to Surgery and a little anxious BlessedOne2 BlessedOne2

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2009 11:09AM BlessedOne2 wrote: Ladies,  thank you for your suggestions.
Posts.Title: Getting Close to Surgery and a little anxious BlessedOne2 BlessedOne2

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2010 12:05PM BlessedOne2 wrote: LovelyLady, I can feel your anxiety and you will be in my prayers.  I was diagnosed as triple positive.  I took A/C every 21 days for 4 cycles from July 09 to January '10, followed by 12 weekly treatments of Taxol and 11 weekly treatments of Herceptin.  We discontinued Herceptin (we because my doctors and I are a team) because it lowered my ejection fraction much more than the Adryiamicin did. The risk does exist but the affects can be reversed with medication, exercise and heart healthy eating. I was released from my surgeon two weeks after my lumpectomy and started chemo about 3 weeks later.  I started radiation about 2 weeks after my last Taxol treatment. I was blessed to "breeze through A/C" if there is such a thing  with no illness but a few minor aches, some fatigue and neuropathy.  As someone else posted exercise, diet  and attitude can make a hugh difference. If you are a praying person, then you may know that prayer supercedes all of the above. With radiation, I took 6 weeks of radiation on my right breasts - that was daily x5 so about 30 treatments.  Each treatment only last a few minutes.   Lovelylady, be encouraged to continue to ask your questions here.  As you can see, we are very willing to share our experiences with anyone who has to join us in this community.  Take care and remember to breath.   Hugs, Wanda
Posts.Title: Anyone taking Adriamycin for Chemo Lovelyface Lovelyface

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 04:55AM BlessedOne2 wrote: Eldub, thank you for sharing your knowledge.  I go to see the surgeon and radiologist tomorrow and will get more details.  nja922, I'm not sure what BL means.  Maybe some of the other ladies may respond to your post. You will find so much information and compassion on these boards. Wanda
Posts.Title: IDC and DCIS BlessedOne2 njdarcy

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 08:31PM BlessedOne2 wrote: Kendall, take deep breaths often.  I'm glad you took your trip and I hope that you had a wonderful time. Susan B. Love's book is an excellent resource.  It is a very thick book so only read the sections you need at the time.   As someone has already said,  don't get too far ahead with your thoughts or your reading. I too suggest that you follow your PCP's recommendation and see an oncologist.  It may depend on whether you go to a major treatment center or smaller office, but they will ask for all of your reports -  Mammo, ultrasound, biopsy, pathology, film and possibly CDs etc. This can take a little time.  Remember that waiting is so very much a part of the initial process before surgery.  Afterwards things seem to move faster.     Call the doctor you saw and request a copy of all of your reports for yourself as well.   I chose to go to a major treatment center and see an oncologist rather than (excuse the term) a local breast surgeon.  I preferred the multi-disciplinary team approach.     The oncologist may also recommend a BRCA test, which is simply a blood stick to see if you carry a hereditary gene.  If so, this may impact the surgical decision.    Here's another suggestion:  talk to your insurance co to learn what your benefits are for this. Once you have a doctor's name, check to see if they participate in your network before making an appointment (otherwise your costs will be higher) Much of this can be done online so you don't have to wait until office is open.  Know that many prayers are being said for you.  Hughs, Wanda

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 05:42PM BlessedOne2 wrote: I finished my rads in March.  My center gave me samples of Aquaphor for use during most of treatment and then RadX just before my boosts.  I tanned pretty well but didn't burn.  Also I think the RadX was helpful when my skin started to peel afterwards - no discomfort at all.    Here's hoping that you all finish your tx well.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 09:26PM BlessedOne2 wrote: Hi Dad5309, Here's my experience to being diagnosed with IDC/right breast: ultrasound and core needle biopsy.  Ultrasound showed that there appears to be no lymph node involvement.  CT scan, chest xray and bone scan  shows the same.  My needle localization(lumpectomy) is next week.  They will do a sentinal node biopsy which will be the definitive test at this point to confirm whether or not there is lymph node involvement.    Although I was told I am Stage IIa, this will be confirmed for me at or after surgery. be encouraged,  wandab

We can make our best plans and do our best to take care of our bodies and still this beast  invades us.  For some practical tips - pray and if you belong to a church, get others to intercede for you; stay knowledgable and participate in your treatment planning;, if you have dietary concerns and your cancer center offers the services of a nutritionist - make an appointment.  Peace be with you. Eliz46 - the wig thing is not for me either.  I had long, thick hair that I cut in June.  My hair has been coming out since day 15 post first treatment.  I will probably get it all cut off tomorrow before I go for tx2.  It is tough trying to decide what to go with (hats, scarves, caps or all)  especially when I didn't do either before BC. It's time to experiment with some new looks and styles. Shae - You are in my prayers.  Try to let go of your grandson's situation and Let God handle it. He is still in control. Tara - You're definitely in the right place for support, encouragement and guidance.  Hair usually doesn't fall out immediately so you have some time to get it cut between your 1st and 2nd tx.  It may help to get it cut twice so that it isn't so overwhelming for you.   What chemo will you be starting with?  I have having my second tx of A/C tomorrow.   Be strong for me and I'll be strong for you.
